MISF, MISF General
58.1 MISF General
� General Information
The goal of the MISF is execute a mis?re monitoring according legal requirements (conditions, engine area,
errors & symptoms handling...) and provide to the ERRM aggregate following CARB mis?re legal informations
to manage the MIL and corresponding error Pcodes
? CARB A mis?re failure criterion:
Risk of catalyst damage, monitoring interval over 200 crankshaft during the driving cycle.
? CARB B1 mis?re failure criterion:
Emission increase, monitoring interval over the ?rst 1000 crankshaft revolutions of the
driving cycle.
? CARB B4 mis?re failure criterion:
Emission increase, monitoring interval over 1000 crankshaft revolutions. For error
detection, mis?re must be take place for 4 monitoring intervals (consecutive or not).

Figure 58.1.1:
58.1.1 Description of the containing functions
B00E - Crankshaft oscillation detection
The crankshaft oscillation detection module uses engine roughness components to identify drivetrain oscilla-

MISF, MISF General
tions than could cause wrong mis?re detections in a de?ned engine operating area. If such oscillation occurs,
this module triggers a fade-out.
B002 - Rough road detection
The rough road detection module uses informations coming from wheel speed sensor(s) or from ABS module
(via harness or CAN) to identify transmission oscillations than could cause wrong mis?re detections in a de?ned
engine operating area. If such oscillation occurs, this module triggers a fade-out.
B03F - Generic mis?re parameters & fade-out conditions
This module provides parameters needed for the mis?re detection process (data delayed, data stacks, and zero
load line...). It also managed all generic mis?re fade-out conditions linked to the mis?re detection method.
B035 - Legal mis?re detection fade-out conditions
This module manages all legal mis?re fade-out conditions de?ned in legal texts (US & EC).
B00T - Mis?re detection - Application incidences
This module de?nes speci?c corrections for detection thresholds, application speci?c fade-out with standard-
ised outputs to the generic modules.
B001 - Mis?re detection
Detection core function based on engine roughness index provided by ENRD.
B00T - Mis?re detection - Application incidences
Some functionality for calibration ease can be launched after detection.
B02E - Mis?re rate determination & error management - Application Incidences
This module de?nes application speci?c fade-out & informations with standardised outputs to the generic
mis?re rate determination module. Diagnosis conditions are de?ned in this module.
Must be executed before B00U module.
B00U - Mis?re rate determination & error management
This module de?nes the Mis?re criterions according legal texts description (MIS_A = mis?re damage catalyst
criterion, MIS_B1 = mis?re emission criterion at engine warm-up & MIS_B4 = mis?re emission criterion) and
identify the cylinders in failures
B02E - Mis?re rate determination & error management - Application Incidences
This module de?nes mis?re errors according the type chosen by NC_TREAT_DIAG_MIS: errors de?ned per
mis?re criterions or errors de?ned per cylinder.
Failures like Mis?re with low fuel tank level, Multiple cylinder mis?re, Random cylinder mis?re are also managed
in this module.
Must be executed after B00U module.
F001 - Mis?re Tuning Functions
This module allows to generate mis?re patterns (continuous or pseudo random) via injection and/or ignition
shut-off interfaces.
This module is optionnal and can be integrated during validation and calibration stages. It is strongly rec-
ommended to remove this functionally on serial product software (integration choice via NC_USE_MIS_GEN
compilation switch).

58.3.1 THRESHOLD OFFSET FOR MEAN ER VALUE
#IF NLC_CONF_ER_MV = 1
� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
A offset (THD_AD_ER_MV) is added to THD_ER, as long as mean er value calculation has not been realised near
Zero Load Line. Means the fuel on adaptation has not adapted the lowest calibrated load break point
in the adaptation map.
The table IP_THD_AD_ER_MV_yy de?nes the size of this table.
LDPM_N_32_IP_ER_MV and LDPM_LOAD_MIS_IP_ER_MV are only used to calculate the current working point.
� Application conditions:
Initialisation: at ECU reset, at Engine Stop To Runing
THD_AD_ER_MV = 0
THD_AD_ER_MV_BUF[all values] = 0
Recurrence: Segment
Activation: LV_ENA_ER = 1
Deactivation: LV_ENA_ER = 0
� Formula section:
For i = (NC_SIZE_THD_ER_BUF-1) to (i >0)
THD_AD_ER_MV_BUF[i] = THD_AD_ER_MV_BUF [i-1]
Endfor
Determination of current working point by using IP_THD_AD_ER_MV _yy.
The results (index and factors) are set in :
IDX_N_AREA, IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR, FAC_N_32_AR, FAC_LOAD_MIS_AR.
If ( (ER_MV_IDX [SEG_NR, IDX_N_AREA, IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR] = IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR+1 )
&& (ER_MV_IDX [SEG_NR, IDX_N_AREA, IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR + 1] = IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR + 2 )
&& (ER_MV_IDX [SEG_NR, IDX_N_AREA + 1, IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR] = IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR+1 )
&& (ER_MV_IDX [SEG_NR, IDX_N_AREA + 1, IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR + 1] = IDX_LOAD_MIS_AR + 2 )
&& (bit x,x+1 of ER_AD_AR[SEG_NR] = 1) )
Then THD_AD_ER_MV_BUF[0] = 0
Else THD_AD_ER_MV_BUF[0] =
IP_THD_AD_ER_MV[IDX_THD_AFS_ER_TRANS_TYP] (N_32, LOAD_MIS)
EndIf
// X represents the current working point for the engine speed : IDX_N_AREA.
THD_AD_ER_MV = THD_AD_ER_MV_BUF[NC_SIZE_THD_ER_BUF -1]
Remark : for the ?rst and last working points on the LDP, the check will be done only with 1 bit.
#ENDIF

58.3.2 MEAN ER VALUE CALCULATION
#IF NLC_CONF_ER_MV = 1
� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
This function allows to determinate the mean values for each cylinders.
ER_MV_CYL_AD[x] and ER_MV_CYL[x] represent the Mean values of ER or ER_STND signal given NLC_USE_ER_
STND value.
� Application conditions:
Initialisation:
All variables not in SRAM are initialised to 0 at ECU reset, at Engine Stop To Runing
Exception: CTR_ ST_ER_FIL = C_CTR_ST_ER_FIL
N_32_GRD_MIS is ?rst time calculated when N_32 stack have been ?ll in (4 segments).
The following variables are initialised when
? ECU is initialised for the ?rst time (?ash memory formatting)
? A loss of adaptation values has been detected (?ash memory corrupted).
? At NVMY clear
ER_AD_AR = 0
ER_MV_MEM[x,y,z] = 0
ER_MV_IDX [x,y,z] = 0
CTR_ER_AD_AR = 0
LV_ER_AR_AVL = 0
ER_MV_CYL[x] = 0
For x = 0 ... [NC_CYL_NR-1]
ER_MV_CYL_AD[x] = ER_MV_MEM[x,1,1]
EndFor
Recurrence: Segment
Activation: LV_ENA_ER = 1
Deactivation: LV_ENA_ER = 0
58.3.2.1 Determination of the calibration for Low Pass Filter :
� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
Calculation of Mean Value is realised by a Low Pass Filter, de?ned by a calibration.
The mean value calculation is only appropriate in case mis?re free operation is ensured. Otherwise the mis?re
detection is self - locked by feeding the segments deviations via the mean value into the ?ltered ER values
causing the mis?re detection to be not able to detect mis?re any more. Also in case of pre ignition (PI) it
has to be ensured that the increased segment times of cylinder segment n?1 caused by PI on cylinder n
are not fed into the mean value calculation of the cylinder segment time n?1 to ensure proper con?rmation
of pre ignition event. Therefore the mean value calculation of ER has to be frozen (STATE_ER_MV_CY L_AD =
6H(FREEZE_PI) or 4H (READ_MEM)) in case of detected pre ignition (CTR_MIS_PI_CYL[NC_CYL_NR] =/= 0) or
in case of adaptation values are available the adaptation values (ER_MV_MEM_CYL[SEG_NR_ER]) have to be
read. This mean value calculation is inhibited as long as the mis?re monitoring window is requested by knock
control PI detection (CTR_MIS_PI_CYL[NC_CYL_NR] =/= 0).
There is a logical ?eld LF_ER_MV_PI_DET indicating the mis?re monitoring window active (bit=1) on Cyl. n?1
due to pre ignition suspected by knock control on Cyl. n.
Generally in case of transient conditions (Load or Engine Speed) the frozen mean value may no longer be
?tting to the real conditions. Therefore there is the possibility to abort the freezing condition to STATE_ER_MV_
CYL_AD = 4H (READ_MEM).
2 thresholds for gradients are de?ned. Thus 3 areas:

? Low gradients =>mean value calculation is enabled
? high gradients =>if adaptation took place, take adapted values, otherwise calculated mean value
? Very high gradient =>take adapted values in any case. Thus if no adaptation occured, Er mean values
are reset ( take value 0)
Given the driving conditions (stabilised, acceleartions, ...), value of the calibration must be different to minimize
the gap between real ER value and his mean value.
In case, of mis?re, to avoid wrong calculation of mean value ( and after miss detection), we will use a calibration,
which will be set to 0 ( or near 0) to freeze the mean value calculation.

Function description:
ER strategy mis?re detection is based on a comparison between a cylinder speci?c ER value (nominal or
normalised) and a threshold who is relative to the engine parameters when this same cylinder was in intake
phase (threshold relative to combustion conditions image).
The engine roughness value ER depends strongly on the current operating point, both in its spread during
undisturbed engine operation, and in the signal amplitude in case of an actual mis?re.
ER mis?re detection thresholds are de?ned according basic threshold maps and threshold corrections:
A basic threshold map:
This map is function of engine load and speed which are calibrated for engine at operating temperature as
well as for adapted transmitter gear. One map is assigned through the vehicle transmission type, idle speed
condition & the combustion mode.
A threshold temperature correction:
A temperature correction is applied to compensate larger signal amplitudes arise of ER values at lower engine
temperatures. This correction is relative to TCO value.
A threshold correction during active injection valve cut-off:
If one or several injection valves are cut off selectively by the engine management system (IV diagnoses ...),
then the cylinder or cylinders are excluded from the mis?re check. Due to the system, the signal amplitude

absolute amount of the threshold can be reduced multiplicatively with the factor IP_FAC_THD_IV_ER(N_32) or

MISF, Mis?re detection
The system identi?es mis?ring by monitoring engine roughness index. Mis?ring causes the angular velocity
of the crankshaft to drop in an angular range speci?c to the cylinder in question.
Mis?re detection is based on nominal engine roughness (ER) by using THD_ER detection threshold.
The identi?cation of the cylinder(s) detected in mis?re is realised according SEG_NR_ER segment reference
(see de?nition and scheme in ENRD aggregate) (Chapter system variables).
THD_ER is already phased according ER delay.
(see detection thresholds management).
Mis?re cylinder fade out carrier de?nition:
MIS_DET_CYL_INH : Carrier used for cylinder fade-out reference
Shows the cylinders that will be in fade-out during the detection phase
MIS_STATE_ER : Carrier used for identi?cation of the cylinder detected in mis?re
Shows the cylinders that will be detected in mis?re

58.4.3 Mis?re detection threshold based on engine roughness value (THD_ER)
� General Information
By using the ER value for mis?re detection, the engine speed has the greatest in?uence on basic thresholds
de?nition. On the other hand, by using the ER_STND values for mis?re detection, the engine load has the
greatest in?uence on basic thresholds de?nition.
The in?uence of the engine load on the detection thresholds can change rapidly during in stationary operation,
it is urgently necessary to determine and to temporarily store the threshold values already at the time of the
actual combustion before the calculatory check.

58.4.3.2 Mis?re detection threshold buffers management
To manage the delay between cylinder intake phase and cylinder ER values, buffers are used to store threshold
values before using for detection.
THD_ER_BUF[NC_SIZE_THD_ER_BUF] buffer is managed as a FIFO stack.
THD_ER_BUF[0] threshold value is the one obtained at current segment.
THD_ER is threshold value delayed and who will be used for detection with current segment ER value. This
delay between ER value and cylinder corresponding threshold depends on engine cylinder number (NC_CYL_
NR).

58.5.1 Mis?re detection threshold correction gain speci?c to application
� Description:
In case of heavy catalyst heating the mis?re detection thresholds have to be corrected, which can be done via
FAC_THD_APP_ER.
� Application conditions
Activation: LV_ENA_SEG_T_MES = 1
And LC_MIS_INH = 0
Deactivation: LV_ENA_SEG_T_MES= 0
Or LC_MIS_INH = 1
Initialisation: ECU reset Or on Deactivation event
FAC_THD_APP_ER = 1
IDX_THD_AFS_ER_TRANS_TYP = 0
Recurrence: updated every segment before misfire detection function
� Formula section:
IDX_THD_AFS_ER_TRANS_TYP=ID_IDX_THD_AFS_ER_TRANS_TYP(STATE_TRANS_TYP)
If TQ_ADD_CH >0
Then
FAC_THD_APP_ER = IP_FAC_THD_APP_ER_CH[IDX_THD_AFS_ER_TRANS_TYP] *
IP_FAC_THD_APP_ER_TQ_ADD_CH
Else
FAC_THD_APP_ER = 1
Endif

58.5.5 Mis?re detection inhibition related to application
� FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
Mis?re detection process can be inhibited when one of the following function requires an inhibition.
As a special case mis?re detection can also be inhibited while some special shorttrips are active. Which short-
trips deactivate mis?re detection is con?gurated with the constant C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL.
� Application conditions
Activation: LV_ENA_ER = 1
And LC_MIS_INH = 0
Deactivation: LV_ENA_ER = 0
Or LC_MIS_INH = 1
Initialisation: at ECU reset Or Engine Stop Or at deactivtion even
LV_INH_APP_DET_MIS = 0
LV_FDOUT_EOL = 0
Recurrence: updated every segment before misfire detection function
� Formula section:
De?nition of inhibition of mis?re detection while shorttrip:
IF LC_FDOUT_EOL = 1
AND ( (LV_ACT_SA_EOL = 1
AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 0] = 1)
OR ((LV_DIAG_EOL_DYN_LS_UP_1 = 1 OR LV_DIAG_EOL_DYN_LS_UP_2 = 1)
AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 1] = 1)
OR ((LV_DIAG_EOL_LAM_ADJ_1 = 1OR LV_DIAG_EOL_LAM_ADJ_2 = 1)
AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 2] = 1)
OR ((LV_DIAG_EOL_REQ_LS_UP_DOWN_1 = 1OR LV_DIAG_EOL_REQ_LS_UP_DOWN_2 = 1)
AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 3] = 1)
OR ((LV_DIAG_TRIP_ENA_VCP[NC_IDX_CAM_VCP_IN_1]
#IF NLC_IVVT_EX = 1
OR LV_DIAG_TRIP_ENA_VCP[NC_IDX_CAM_VCP_EX_1])
#ENDIF
AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 4] = 1)
OR (LV_DIAG_EOL_CAT = 1
AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 5] = 1)
OR (LV_EOL_CPS = 1
File: AEB00T01.00V

AND C_CONF_FDOUT_EOL[Bit 6] = 1))
OR (LC_MVB_EOL_FDOUT_MIS =1
AND ID_MVB_EOL_FDOUT_MIS == 1)
THEN LV_FDOUT_EOL = 1
ENDIF
Inhibition of mis?re detection:
L V_N_MAX_MIS is a temporay data.
LV_N_MAX_MIS = LV_N_MAX // General Fade-Out if LV_N_MAX = 1
If (LC_APP_MIS_N_MAX = 1 and LV_N_MAX_MIS = 1)
Then
If (LV_N_MAX_VST = 1 and (N_32 / C_N_MAX_xx) >C_APP_MIS_IS_N_MAX) // xx= AT, MT, CVT, DCT
Then LV_N_MAX_MIS = 0 // No Fade-Out if LV_N_MAX was set
ElseIf ((VS_HIGH_RES / C_VS_MAX) >C_APP_VS_MAX)
Then LV_N_MAX_MIS = 0 // No Fade-Out if LV_N_MAX was set
//by vehicle-speed-limitation
EndIf
EndIf
EndIf
If LV_FID_READY = 1
Then ACTION_FARM_GetPermission(<NC_FID_MIS_INH_APP>, <LV_PRMS_TMP>)
Endif
While the combustion manager is in transient state, the mis?re detection can be disabled to have a proper
base for evaluation of the ER-mis?re detection thresholds, which are de?ned for the stationary modes from

58.5.5.1 Detection of Stucked Dual Mass Fly-Wheel (DMF)
� Description:
In case of fast release of clutch with loaded gear, the dual mass ?y-wheel stucks into pull positon. After in-
creasing the engine load the DMF leaves the stucked position gradually. During this phase, the DMF causes
oscillations which has an inpact on the measured segment time that leads to high engine roughness peaks.
Those can lead to wrong Mis?re detection.
Aim is, to observe the DMF behaviour and con?rm if it s blocked. Further more, the Lambda offset (difference
between setpoint and actual value) has to be taken in account, in order to distinguish between Mis?re and no
Mis?re case. The offset will show a higher deviation during Mis?re events.
Hence, if Mis?re events are detected during the stucked phase an inhibition of the detection will be activated,
after con?rmation of Lambda offset check.
� Application conditions
Activation: LV_ENA_SEG_T_MES = 1
And LV_SEG_AD_AVL_ER = 1
And LC_MIS_INH = 0
And C_N_MIN_DMF_MIS < N_32 < C_N_MAX_DMF_MIS
And ( LV_AT = 0 Or LV_DCT = 1)
Deactivation: when activation conditions not fulfilled
Initialisation: ECU reset Or on Deactivation event Or IGK off to on
CTR_DMF_CHK = 0
CTR_N_GRD_MAX_DMF = 0
LV_DMF_STUCK = 0
LV_INH_MIS_DMF_STUCK = 0
MIS_LAMB_OFS = 0
ER_FIL_RATIO_DMF = 0
ER_DELTA_FIL_MEM_RATIO_DMF = 0
Recurrence: Updated every segment

58.5.8 Mis?re detection calibration ease
� General information:
For calibration ease, a ratio between ER (or ER_HB) value and the ER detection threshold can be integrated.
ER values are proportionnal to engine speed, thus the detection and fade-out calibration in transients engine
operating points are choosey. Data visualisation and scalling have always to be updated according current
engine operating point.
After precalibration, with the introduction of such ratio, the mis?re detection check and validation will be much
more easier for tuning team.
Ratio close to zero : no risk of mis?re detected.
Ratio close to 100% or above : mis?re detected by threshold (before fade-out check).
� Application conditions

Deactivation: LV_ENA_ER = 0
Or LC_MIS_INH = 1

� General information
The mis?re detection based on engine roughness index (ER) may be disturbed by crankshaft oscillations
when single mis?re (random) occurs, especially for front drive vehicles crankshaft in the low engine speed
/ high engine load area (in combination with a 3rd, 4th or 5th gear ratio). A single mis?re acts as a drivetrain /
crankshaft oscillations trigger, in this case the ER index is distrubed by these oscillations, in some conditions it is
practically not possible to distinguish on ER index, real mis?re towards speed drop caused through crankshaft
speed oscillations.
The trigger for such oscillations can be a single mis?re, an obstacle, a big torque change or others instanta-
neous conditions.
The principle of this crankshaft / drivetrain oscillation detection is to detect such an oscillation and then to
fade-out the mis?re detection for a short period to avoid over-detection.
Initialisation: on ECU reset, on LC_MIS_INH 0 to 1 transition
SEG_SUM_FRQ_CRK_OSC = 0
DRV0_ER_SUM_OSC = 0
LV_STATE_CRK_OSC = 0

ElseIf CTR_TDC_CRK_OSC_ACT 0
Then CTR_TDC_CRK_OSC_ACT = CTR_TDC_CRK_OSC_ACT - 1
EndIf
If LV_ENA_ER = 1
And LC_MIS_INH = 0
And LV_INH_CRK_OSC_DET = 0
And N_32 < C_N_MAX_CRK_OSC

MISF, Crankshaft oscillation detection

Update rate: Segment
58.6.1 Detection description
The ?nal decision about crankshaft oscillation consists of two parts:
? The detection of a critical engine roughness oscillation frequency.
? The detection of a critical engine roughness oscillation amplitude.
If both parts ful?lled at the same time their own detection criterion, a crankshaft oscillation is detected. The
reason therefore is, that even at constant speed due to normal little speed variations a high frequency or at a
normal acceleration phase a big amplitude is possible.
58.6.1.1 Determination of a critical engine roughness frequency
� Application conditions
Activation: LV_CRK_OSC_DET_ACT = 1
Deactivation: LV_CRK_OSC_DET_ACT = 0
� Formula section:
If Bit sign between DRV0_ER(n?1)and DRV0_ER(n)changes
Then SEG_SUM_FRQ_CRK_OSC = IP_SEG_MIN_FRQ_CRK_OSC(N_32)
ElseIf SEG_SUM_FRQ_CRK_OSC 0
Then SEG_SUM_FRQ_CRK_OSC = SEG_SUM_FRQ_CRK_OSC - 1
EndIf
If SEG_SUM_FRQ_CRK_OSC 0
Then LV_FRQ_CRIT_CRK_OSC = 1 // Critical crankshaft frequency status is active
Else LV_FRQ_CRIT_CRK_OSC = 0
EndIf
58.6.1.2 Determination of a critical engine roughness oscillation amplitude
� Application conditions
Activation: LV_CRK_OSC_DET_ACT = 1
Deactivation: LV_CRK_OSC_DET_ACT = 0
� Formula section:
If Bit sign between DRV0_ER(n?1)and DRV0_ER(n)changes
Then DRV0_ER_SUM_OSC(n) = DRV0_ER(n)
Else DRV0_ER_SUM_OSC(n) = DRV0_ER_SUM_OSC(n?1) + DRV0_ER(n)
// with saturation
EndIf
DRV0_ER_SUM_THD_OSC = IP_DRV0_ER_THD_OSC(N_32, LOAD_MIS)
If DRV0_ER_SUM_OSC DRV0_ER_SUM_THD_OSC
Then LV_AMPL_CRIT_CRK_OSC = 1 // Critical crankshaft amplitude status is active
Else LV_AMPL_CRIT_CRK_OSC = 0
EndIf

If in the same time, both conditions are active, a crankshaft oscillation status is triggered :
If LV_FRQ_CRIT_CRK_OSC = 1
And LV_AMPL_CRIT_CRK_OSC = 1
Then After condition rising edge triggering, LV_STATE_CRK_OSC ?ag is set to 1 as long as condition is
true.
After condition falling edge triggering, LV_STATE_CRK_OSC ?ag is hold to 1 for a period of C_DLY_
TDC_CRK_OSC tdc?s, even if LV_CRK_OSC_DET_ACT is then set to 0.
EndIf

58.7.2 Rough road detection via Wheel Speed (LC_RR_TCS = 0)
� General Information
Rough road conditions must be detected to prevent erroneous mis?re detection because of the in?uence jolt
tracks have on the crankshaft as a result of transmission via the drive train.
The speed disturbance of the driven wheels can be used to calculate the rough road conditions. For this, CAN
wheel speed signals from the driven wheels are analysed
The wheel signal to be used can be selected by C_CONF_WHEEL_DET_RR
The validity of wheel-speed-signals is checked in CAN-chapter.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at reset or deactivation
WHEEL_GRD_FN_RI = 0
WHEEL_GRD_ FN_LE = 0
WHEEL_GRD_RE_RI = 0
WHEEL_GRD_RE_LE = 0
WHEEL_GRD = 0
WHEEL_GRD_MMV = 0
SUM_RR_WHEEL = 0
Activation: Same as CAN message
if LC_RR_TCS = 0
and ACTION_FARM_GetPermission (NC_FID_INH_RR_WS) = 1 // valid
wheel-speed signals from CAN
and C_VS_MIN_RR < VS < C_VS_MAX_RR // vehicle speed within
window
Deactivation: if one of the above condition is not fulfilled
Recurrence: Same as CAN message

For the ?rst calculation when the activation conditions are covered, the old values CAN_WHEEL_xx_yyn?1 and

WHEEL_xx_yyn
All wheel speed gradients are continuously calculated. The choice of the gradient to be used for the Rough
Road detection is perform afterwards according to a con?guration choice C_CONF_WHEEL_DET_RR

MISF, Rough road detection
58.7.2.2 Wheel Speed Gradient ?ltering calculation
The raw value WHEEL_GRD so obtain is used in a moving mean averaging, to restrict suppression to actual
rough road conditions.
Formula section:
// Determination of WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR
The correlation constant WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR depends on whether WHEEL_GRD increases or decreases
If WHEEL_GRDn ? WHEEL_GRD_MMVn?1
then WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR = C_WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR_INC
else WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR = C_WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR_DEC
Endif
// Filtering calculation
WHEEL_GRD_MMVn= WHEEL_GRD_MMVn?1 +
WHEEL_GRD_CRLC_RR * [WHEEL_GRDn - WHEEL_GRD_MMVn?1]
58.7.2.3 Detection of rough road status via wheel speed
When the detection of rough road is effective, then the logical value LV_STATE_RR_WHEEL is activated for a
period of C_DLY_ER_RR. This duration is triggered again with every violation of the threshold.
Formula section:
WHEEL_GRD_MMV_THD = IP_WHEEL_GRD_MMV_THD__VS
If ACTION_FARM_GetPermission (NC_FID_INH_RR_WS) = 1
Then
If WHEEL_GRD_MMV ? WHEEL_GRD_MMV_THD
then LV_STATE_RR_WHEEL = 1 for C_DLY_ER_RR ms
SUM_RR_WHEELn = SUM_RR_WHEELn?1 + 1
endif
Else LV_STATE_RR_WHEEL = LC_STATE_RR_LIH
EndIf

� General Information
58.8.1 Mis?re detection engine parameters
� General Information
In order to cover all the combustion states of an engine (Hom. AFS, AFL & Strat.) in torque based engine
control, a general variable LOAD_MIS that represents the ratio of engine load ? whatever should be the load
de?nition depending on engine combustion state ( eg. MAF in Hom. and TQI_AV in Strat. ) ? is de?ned for the
purpose of the Mis?re function and the calculation of the ER-mis?re detection thresholds.
Depending on the project choice con?guration (with C_CONF_LOAD_MIS), in Homogenous combustion mode
this Mis?re load variable should be either MAF, MAP or TQI_AV. In the other hand this Mis?re load variable is
always TQI_AV in Strati?ed combustion mode.
Legally, the presence of engine mis?re in the engine operating region is bounded by the positive torque line
(i.e. engine load with the transmission in neutral) and an engine speed value.
The zero load line is a function of the engine speed and depends on the engine combustion mode (for GDI
application), coolant temperature and atmospheric pressure.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: All variables are initialised to 0 at reset, at engine stop
Or at LC_MIS_INH 0 to 1 transition
LOAD_GRD_MIS is first time calculated when LOAD_MIS stack have
been fill in (4 segments).
Activation: LV_ENA_SEG_T_MES = 1
And LC_MIS_INH = 0
Deactivation: LV_ENA_SEG_T_MES = 0
Or LC_MIS_INH = 1
Recurrence: every segment task
� Function Description
Normalised engine load dedicated to misfire detection
For each misfire segment, the following stack is serviced:
LOAD_MIS_3 =LOAD_MIS_2
LOAD_MIS_2 =LOAD_MIS_1
LOAD_MIS_1 = LOAD_MIS
If C_CONF_LOAD_MIS = 0
Or LV_S_ACT = 1
Then LOAD_MIS_Temp = TQI_AV / IP_TQI_AV_MAX_MIS(N_32) // TQI_AV based
ElseIf C_CONF_LOAD_MIS = 1
Then LOAD_MIS_Temp = MAF / IP_MAF_MAX_MIS(N32) // MAF based
Else LOAD_MIS_Temp = MAP / C_MAP_MAX_MIS // MAP based
EndIf
LOAD_MIS = FAC_GAIN_LOAD_MIS * LOAD_Temp // Application incidence correction
LOAD_GRD_MIS = | LOAD_MIS - LOAD_MIS_3 |
Note : LOAD_MIS calculation steps are checked against division by zero
LOAD_MIS_Temp is a non visible, temporary value

58.8.2 Generic fade out conditions for mis?re detection
� General Information
Generic fade out (LV_REQ_APP_INH_MIS) is based on all conditions who could create unreliable conditions for
mis?re detection :
? Engine gradients (engine load, throttle, combustion mode & ignition angle transients).
? Crankshaft jolt effects who can distrub detection process (rough road, drivetrain oscillations, air condi-
tionner & accessoiries activation/deactivation).
? OBDI errors on one of the sensors used by the mis?re monitoring process.
All these different conditions are merge into a carrier (MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH).
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at ECU reset, at Engine Stop Or at LC_MIS_INH 0 to 1 transition
LV_REQ_APP_INH_MIS = 1
MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH = 2047
MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH_NR = 11
MAP_DIF_MIS = 0
IGA_DIF_MIS = 0
IGA_BAS_DIF_MIS = 0
IGA_MIS_2 = 0
IGA_MIS_1 = 0
IGA_MIS = 0
Activation: LV_ENA_ER = 1
And LC_MIS_INH = 0
Deactivation: LV_ENA_ER = 0
Or LC_MIS_INH = 1
Remark : Timers used for delay are 10 ms free running decounters,
they are not linked to activation/deactivation conditions described
above.
Recurrence: segment task for data process
10 ms for free running timers

58.8.4 Generic fade out conditions for mis?re detection : Con?gurable generic fade-out
management
� General Information
Generic fade out management during zero delay phase, nominal phase & idle speed engine state can be
con?gurated via 3 bit?eld masks that allow to take in account or not some conditions in a phase and not in the
other.
If the corresponding bit in the MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH carrier structure is set to 0 in C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_
ZDLY_MIS, C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS or C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS_IS calibration, then the corresponding
condition will not fade-out mis?re detection.
For the de?nition of C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS, C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS & C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_
MIS_IS masks please refer to the legal requirements & customer recommendations.

58.8.8 Generic fade out conditions for mis?re detection : Ignition retardation without
change limitation
� General Information
Various functions or CAN requests (e.g.. gear-shift signal. torque reduction. etc...) cause an ignition - timing re-
tardation, without change limitation. Mis?re detection can be disabled when the amount of the ignition timing
retardation is too important.
Several criterion are available to disable the mis?re monitoring according the ignition angle behaviour. Two
relative criterions dedicated to focus on IGA transients, one in idle speed and one in part load, plus one absolute
criterion dedicated to focus on too important IGA values compared to the
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: at ECU reset, at Engine Stop Or at LC_MIS_INH 0 to 1 transition
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS = 1
� Function Description
For each TDC, the following stacks are serviced after having calculated IGA_
AV_x.
IGA_DIF_MIS = | IGA_MIS_2 - IGA_MIS |
IGA_BAS_DIF_MIS = IGA_BAS_COR_MV - IGA_MIS
IGA_MIS_2 = IGA_MIS_1
IGA_MIS_1 = IGA_MIS
IGA_MIS = IGA_AV[SEG_NR]
IGA_DIF_MIS = | IGA_MIS_2 - IGA_MIS |
If(1) LV_S_ACT = 0
Then(1)
If(2) LV_IS = 1
And N_32 < C_N_32_MAX_IGA_IS_MIS
Then(2)
If(3) IGA_DIF_MIS > IP_DELTA_IGA_IS_MIS(TCO, LOAD_MIS_2)
Then(3) After condition rising edge triggering,
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS flag is set to 1 as long as
condition is true.
Else(3) After condition falling edge triggering,
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS flag is hold to 1 for a
period of C_NR_TDC_IGA_DIF_IS_MIS.
When this period is exceeded without retriggering,
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS releases to 0.
EndIf(3)
Else(2) // out of idle speed conditions
If(3) IGA_DIF_MIS > IP_DELTA_IGA_MIS(N_32, LOAD_MIS)
Then(3) After condition rising edge triggering,
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS flag is set to 1 as long as
condition is true.
Else(3) After condition falling edge triggering,
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS flag is hold to 1 for a
period of C_NR_TDC_IGA_DIF_MIS.
When this period is exceeded without retriggering,
LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS releases to 0.
EndIf(3)
EndIf(2)
If(2) LV_IGA_GRD_ACT = 0 // out of IGA engine start calculation phase
And IGA_BAS_DIF_MIS > IP_DELTA_IGA_BAS_MIS(N_MIS,LOAD_MIS)
Then(2) After condition rising edge triggering,

� General Information
General information
This chapter is relative to mis?re detection fade out management as de?ned by legal texts linked to functionnal
OBD diagnosis (OBDII, EOBD...).
Continuous mis?re monitoring from engine starting instant:
Engine start instant : the point when the engine reaches a speed 150 rpm below the normal, warmed-up
idle speed (as determined in the drive position for vehicles equipped with an automatic transmission) (CARB
de?nition).
One engine cycle (2 crankshaft revolutions) is allowed to initialise mis?re detection process (see CTR_TDC_
ZDLY_MIS using).
Fade out conditions may disable mis?re monitoring with the following conditions:
Minimum engine speed : N_IS_SP - 150 rpm (US)
Maximum engine speed : Redline engine speed (US) or 4500 rpm (EC)
Minimum engine load :
Zero load line (engine positive torque line)
A line joining the point (3000 rpm, zero load) and a point (6000 rpm, 135 hPa (or 4 inches Hg) above the zero
load line)
Minimum coolant or ambiant temperature
Below 20�F (US) or -7�C (EC) (equivalent),
Or If Engine start coolant temperature is below 20�F, until current temperature reaches warm up engine tem-
perature 70�F.
Minimum atmospheric pressure
Elevations above 8000 feet above sea level (US) or 2 500 meters (EC)
Time after start
A 5s time after start fade-out can be allowed for EC market
Such kind of fade out is prohibited for US market (see CARB requirement for zero delay mis?re monitoring
activation)
Cylinder shut-off
During fuel cut-off phase, on a speci?c cylinder shut-off or the number of cylinder in shut-off is too important,
mis?re diagnosis may be fade out (no injection/combustion occurs)

Figure 58.9.1:
58.9.1 Mis?re detection fade out management
� General Information
FUNCTION DESCRIPTION:
CARB requests an activation of the mis?re monitoring and diagnosis as off engine start. Particular fade-out
conditions are required during the ?rst 5 seconds since engine running. In this section the ?ag representing
the request is de?ned, and is used in several other modules that are concerned with this requirement (LC_
REQ_ZDLY_MIS = 1).
File: 30B03504.00D
23400
Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
MISF, Legal mis?re detection fade-out conditions
For non-CARB applications, this special monitoring is not required and has to be de-activated (LC_REQ_ZDLY_
MIS = 0).
A state-based approach is taken for the activation of the mis?re detection algorithms, distinguishing the sep-
arate monitoring during the ?rst 5 seconds and the ?nominal? monitoring afterwards, and preparatory phases.
During the monitoring phases, the normal fade-out mechanisms are used, corrected for some fade-outs that
are not allowed during the ?rst 5 seconds.
The counter CTR_T_ZDLY_MIS is decremented at every time instance of 10 ms when STATE_DIAG_MIS != 0.
The counter CTR_TDC_ZDLY_MIS is decremented with 1 at every TDC.
(both counters are saturated to 0)
At engine start-up (LV_RUN_ENG switches from 0 to 1) the system starts in STATE_DIAG_MIS = 0 (initialisation
phase).
In the case of a CARB-application, special monitoring takes placed during C_T_ZDLY_MIS seconds. The timer is
started at detection of engine running.
Rermark: During the 0-delay mis?re detection, no fade-outs are allowed for crankshaft oscillation, rough road
detection and zero-load line conditions (see appropriate sections). However, it is allowed to have so-called
driver-induced fade-outs (e.g. gradient on pedal value). This latter section has been added.
At hot resets, the system starts again in the initialisation phase.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: RST, ERU2ES, ES2ERU
Activation: SEG: LV_RUN_ENG==1
10MS: LV_RUN_ENG==1
Deactivation: LV_RUN_ENG==0
Recurrence: SEG, 10MS

58.9.2 Mis?re detection legal fade out conditions
� General Information
General information:
Legal fade out (LV_REQ_INH_MIS) is based on all fade out conditions allowed by the legal texts for continuous
mis?re monitoring.
All these different fade-out conditions are merge into a global carrier (MIS_DET_CDN_INH).
Timers used for fade-out conditions delays are free running timers who are not deactivated according following
conditions.

58.9.2.3.1 Con?gurable Fade-out Management
Fade out management during zero delay phase & nominal phase can be con?gurated via 2 bit?eld masks that
allow to take in account or not some conditions in a phase and not in the other.
If the corresponding bit in the MIS_DET_CDN_INH carrier structure is set to 0 in C_MASK_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS
or C_MASK_INH_DET_MIS calibration, then the corresponding condition will not fade-out mis?re detection.

If the corresponding bit in the MIS_DET_CDN_INH carrier structure is set to 0 in C_MASK_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS
or C_MASK_INH_DET_MIS calibration, then the corresponding condition will not fade-out mis?re detection.
For the de?nition of C_MASK_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS & C_MASK_INH_DET_MIS masks please refer to the legal re-
quirements & customer recommendations.

58.9.2.3.2 Maximum engine speed fade-out
The mis?re monitoring can be inhibated when the engine speed reachs the maximum engine speed imposed
by the market target : Redline engine speed for US applications or 4500 rpm for EC applications.
Moreover this information is use to stop mis?re monitoring process for high speed if not required (limitation of
cpu load especially for european application).

58.9.2.3.3 Minimum engine speed fade-out
The irregular engine operation test is performed as soon as the above-mentioned condition is disabled.
Important:
C_N_MIN_MIS is de?ned by the current con?guration of the index used for mis?re detection in the current
application. C_N_MIN_MIS should be lower than C_N_MIN_ZDLY_MIS.
C_N_MIN_ZDLY_MIS is de?ned as the engine speed set-point for a warm engine minus 150 rpm. After passing
below the C_N_MIN_ZDLY_MIS threshold, one is allowed one engine cycle (meaning for example for a 4-cylinder
engine 4 tdc?s) before reactivating the output of the mis?re detection algorithm. Mis?re detection is suppressed
for a period of C_NR_TDC_INH_MIS tdc?s.
It should be checked in each application that within the allowed number of TDC?s proper mis?re detection
index values have been re-obtained. Typically, it should be possible to restart mis?re detection earlier.

Application conditions:
N <C_N_MIN_ZDLY_MIS
Engine speed below CARB requirements (used for US applications).
Typically, once N<C_N_MIN_ZDLY_MIS, the output of the mis?re detection is inhibited, allthough the calculation
is still valid. C_NR_TDC_ZDLY_MIS tdc?s decounter is started at passing engine speed C_N_MIN_ZDLY_MIS again.
Once the decounter is at 0, mis?re detection index output is allowed.
N <C_N_MIN_MIS
Engine speed below mis?re detection index resolution (used for CE applications). If the engine speed falls
below C_N_MIN_MIS.

58.9.2.3.8 Injection shut-off
Mis?re detection can be suppressed for the cylinder(s), for which injection has been shut-off.
General fuel shut-off:
LV_INJ_CUT indicates a general fuel shut-off. LV_PUC_DET_MIS bit includes a calibration delay time (C_T_DLY_
IV_OFF_MIS) triggered at fuel cut-off condition falling edge, in a way to start the mis?re detection only after
crankshaft oscillations due to fuel reactivation.
 
LV_INJ_CUT 
C_ T_ DLY_ IV_O FF_ M IS 
LV_PUC_DET_MIS 
Figure 58.9.25:
Cylinder speci?c shut-off:
If the current cylinder checked by mis?re detection is shut-off by any EMS function even MISF limp home
functionnality), a fade-out can be apply for the mis?re detection of this cylinder.
Due to the delay between the mis?re index and the injection current informations, a calibration delay (C_NR_
TDC_IV_OFF_DET_MIS) has been introduced on LV_IV_OFF_DET_MIS.
This delay synchronises MISF & INJR informations in a way to apply correctly the fade-out on the proper
cylinder during individual cylinder shut-off operations, and to be able the perform the mis?re monitoring on
the other cylinders who are not in shut-off mode.

Figure 58.10.1:
Determination of CARB A mis?re criterion, causing catalyst damage
Description:
With a CARB A mis?re rate criterion, the emissions are increased and there is a risk of catalyst damage if the
cylinder causing the failure criterion can not be shut off.
Detection:
The check for mis?re rate violation CARB A comprises 200 crankshaft revolutions (100 * NC_CYL_NR tdc?s) for
statistic mis?ring and cyclewise monitoring for best possible catalyst protection.
If a con?rmed mis?ring is detected on ER current TDC (LV_DET_CFM_MIS=1), a weighting factor (MIS_A_FAC) is
added to the cylinder-speci?c counter MIS_CTR_A[SEG_NR_ER], extracted from an interpolated table (see APP.
INC.) who depends on engine combustion mode and current operating point. The increment represents the
severity of catalyst damage.
Statistic:
The monitoring for Mis?re CARB A is performed continuously in intervals of 200 crankshaft revolutions.

MISF, Mis?re diagnosis CARB A
Monitoring during CARB A window:
To guarantee best possible catalyst protection, the cylinder-speci?c counters are monitored each cycle. For
that purpose, MIS_CTR_A[SEG_NR_ER] is compared to the applicable value C_MIS_A_IND_THD representing the
critical threshold for single cylinder mis?ring.
If the threshold is reached outside of the FTP cycle, the concerning cylinder is shut off immediately. CARB A
mis?re criterion is con?rmed, else the criterion will be evaluated at the end of the 200 crankshaft revolution
window.
Monitoring at the end of 200 crankshaft revolutions:
At the end of each monitoring interval the cylinder-speci?c sums MIS_CTR_A[NC_CYL_NR] and the global sum
(MIS_SUM_A) are available.
If the sum MIS_SUM_A is greater than the threshold C_MIS_SUM_A_THD, the cylinder with the highest mis?re
rate is determined (by comparing the different MIS_CTR_A[NC_CYL_NR] values).
Then operation inside/outside of the FTP-area is checked by comparison of the counter CTR_FTP_CDN_MIS_A
/ MIS_NR_TDC_A with the threshold C_RATIO_FTP_CDN_MIS_A. If the FTP tdc?s ratio is lower than the threshold,
not enough operating points have been inside the FTP-window and therefore operation outside FTP-area is
detected (LV_FTP_MIS_A=0). This is done in order to ful?l the CARB-regulations, which require MIL-illumination
at ?rst threshold exceeding outside the FTP-area and at third exceeding inside the FTP-area.
Therefore the counter CTR_DET_MIS_A is incremented inside the FTP-area at each threshold exceeding. That
means it reaches the maximum of C_NR_DET_MAX_MIS_A = 3 only if the threshold is exceeded in 3 succeeding
monitoring intervals.
Outside the FTP-area the failure CARB A is validated immediately. The counter is reset only after an ECU-
reset.
Even if we are inside the FTP-area, a speci?c application request (according catalyst temperature or else) LV_
REQ_APP_CTR_MIS_A can force to validate immediately the failure CARB A (see legal requirements & customer
wishes). This request is de?ned in associated Application Incidences ?le.
Note: cylinder and Exhaut cylinder bank speci?c counters are respectively indexed with SEG_NR_ER and SEG_
NR_CBK_ER phase reference counters to take in account ERND delay in mis?re monitoring process

MISF, Mis?re diagnosis CARB A
58.10.5.2.2.1.1.2.2.1 Limp Home process
Cylinder shut off is limited by a C_MIS_MAX_NR_OFF_IV maximum number of cylinders that can be shut-off
simultaneously or C_MIS_MAX_NR_OFF_IV_CBK maximum number of cylinders that can be shut off simultane-
ously by bank.
Each time, the mis?re cylinder limp home process on one (or more) cylinder(s) is triggered, the corresponding
cylinder counter(s) CTR_MIS_A_LIH_CYL[NC_CYL_NR] is(are) unitary incremented.
The location of switched off Cylinder(s) x is set to 1 in INH_IV_MIS, other cylinder bits are set to 0.
On the same driving cycle, if after a cylinder shut-off cancellation, a new cylinder MIS_A criterion occurs during
CARB A window, the sytem must shut-off this cylinder once more.

Figure 58.10.42:
58.10.5.2.3.2.2 Criterion detection process
The mis?re detection counter (CTR_DET_MIS_A) is monitored for a calibrated number of CARB A windows,
a. If mis?re is detected during this calibrated period, then the detection counter is incremented. If the detection
counter reaches a threshold, the injection is turned off for the mis?ring cylinder.
b. If no mis?re is detected during this calibrated period, the mis?re detection counter is decremented at the
end of each CARB A window until 0.
By tuning the calibrated window size to 0, only successive detection of mis?re on CARB A window will lead to
injection shut-off for the mis?ring cylinder. The above strategy can be disabled using a switch.

MISF, Mis?re diagnosis CARB A
58.10.5.3 Cylinder reactivation after catalyst cooling
The cylinders which are identi?ed as mis?ring are shut off. The mode of combustion leading to mis?re (DI or
MPI) is determined and the opposite mode (MPI or DI) can be used to run the engine without shutting off the
cylinder. The switching of injection mode is done only after waiting for calibrated number of CARB A windows.
This is required in order to allow cooling of catalyst to protect from damage.
After the end of MPI/DI diagnosis check if ignition is the cause for mis?ring. If it is correct, then deactivate the
injection for speci?c cylinder.

58.10.6 Conditions for Cylinder switch back on
Update rate: every 100ms, independently of MIS_A window process & conditions
Cylinder(s) x can be switched on according two different methods:
Cylinder(s) x can be switched back on at the end of the driving cycle
LC_CONF_INH_IV_MIS = 0
Cylinder(s) x can be switched back on after a de?ned number of fuel cut-off phases and at the end of the
driving cycle
LC_CONF_INH_IV_MIS = 1
For this purpose, the system performs a test for the applicable number C_MIS_MIN_NR_PUC of trailing throttle
fuel cut-off LV_PUC cycles, since the last cylinder(s) shutoff.
Therefore, the trailing throttle fuel cut-off LV_PUC ?ag must have been active for the applicable minimum
period C_T_MIS_MIN_PUC.
If the condition concerning the minimum number of trailing throttle fuel cut-off events is met. Cylinder shut-
off is cancelled at the end of the last trailing throttle fuel cut-off phase only for cylinders who answer to the
conditions CTR_MIS_A_LIH_CYL[x] <C_NR_MAX_MIS_A_LIH_CYL (check for all cylinders), all other cylinders stay
in fuel cut-off up to end of the driving cycle.

MISF, Mis?re diagnosis CARB B
ACTION_MISF_ResetCarbB() Mode: O
Reset the CARB B fault detection data
� Import actions:
ACTION_CBMD_SetInh(IN <PRM_IDX_CMB_INH>)
ACTION_CBMD_SetReq(IN <PRM_IDX_CMB_REQ>)
ACTION_FARM_SetAuxiliaryStatus(IN <PRM_IDX>, IN <PRM_STATE>)
� General Information
The mis?re rate determination and mis?re speci?c error management are applied to the following CARB mis?re
legal de?nitions:
CARB B1 mis?re failure criterion (LV_MIS_STATE_B1):
Emission increase, monitoring interval over the ?rst 1000 crankshaft revolutions (= 1000 * NC_CYL_NR / 2
TDCs) of the driving cycle.
CARB B4 mis?re failure criterion (LV_MIS_STATE_B4):
Emission increase, monitoring interval over 1000 crankshaft revolutions (= 1000 * NC_CYL_NR / 2 TDCs). For
criterion con?rmation, mis?re must be take place for 4 monitoring intervals (consecutive or not).
Determination of CARB B1 & B4 mis?re criterions, causing increased emissions
Description:
The purpose is to detect a mis?re rate causing an emission increase. The failure criterion entry is performed
by direct statistical evaluation.
Detection:
The check for mis?re rate violation CARB comprises 1.000 crankshaft revolutions (500*NC_CYL_NR tdc?s).
Each combustion during these 1.000 crankshaft revolutions is monitored for mis?ring.
If a con?rmed mis?ring is detected on ER current TDC (LV_DET_CFM_MIS=1), the cylinderspeci?c mis?re counter
MIS_CTR_B[SEG_NR_ER] is incremented by one.
In every driving cycle a distinction is made between mis?res detected during the ?rst 1000 crankshaft revs
after engine start (CARB B1) and mis?res detected in later observing intervals. In the second case, a mis?re rate
violation must take place during four monitoring intervals to recognise mis?re (CARB B4).
Statistic:
At the end of the ?rst 1.000 crankshaft revolutions, the added cylinderspeci?c sums are evaluated. If the sum
exceeds the applicable value C_THD_MIS_B1_AT/MT, CARB B1 mis?re criterion is detected.
At the end of each following 1.000 crankshaft revolutions interval, the added cylinderspeci?c sums are evalu-
ated. If the sum exceeds the applicable value C_THD_MIS_B1_AT/MT the antibounce counter CTR_DET_MIS_B4
will be incremented till its maximum C_NR_DET_MAX_MIS_B4 (typical = 3) is reached. If the sum does not
exceed C_THD_MIS_B1_AT/MT, CTR_DET_MIS_B4 remains unchanged.
To ?lter out those cylinders with low mis?re rates, the cylinderspeci?c counters MIS_CTR_B[NC_CYL_NR] shall
be compared to the applicable value C_THD_MIS_B_MIN before storage takes place.
If none of the cylinderspeci?c counters is higher than C_THD_MIS_B_MIN, a maximum choice is done and the
cylinder with the highest mis?re rate is entered into failure memory

ACTION_MISF_ResetMisCdn() Mode: O
Action to clear datas for MISF datas
� General Information
58.12.1 Application Incidences data for diagnosis
� General Information
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: At ECU reset Or LC_MIS_INH 0 to 1 transition
Call of ACTION_MISF_ResetMisCdn
Activation: LC_MIS_INH = 0
Deactivation: LC_MIS_INH = 1
Recurrence: ENRD segment synchronous,
After misfire detection, Before misfire diagnosis
� Function Description
58.12.1.1 Inputs for project speci?c diagnosis functions:
If MAX (TEG_DYN_UP_CAT[NC_CBK_EX_NR]) > C_TEG_DYN_UP_CAT_MIS_A_MAX
Then LV_REQ_APP_CTR_MIS_A = 1
Else LV_REQ_APP_CTR_MIS_A = 0
EndIf
58.12.1.2 Inhibition of mis?re crossed detection with IV- and IGC-OBDI non debounced errors:
LV_INH_IGC_DIAG_MIS = LV_INH_DET_MIS
LV_INH_IV_DIAG_MIS = LV_INH_DET_MIS Or LV_INH_DIAG_IV
58.12.1.3 Request to evaluate CARB A criterion with project speci?c calibration set
FAC_MIS_A_APP must be calculated before "Determination of catalyst damage weighting factor" in the generic
speci?cation named Mis?re Diagnosis CARB A.
If(1) LV_CH = 1
Then(1)
LV_MIS_A_DIAG_REQ_APP = 1
FAC_MIS_A_THD_IND_APP = C_FAC_MIS_A_THD_IND_APP
FAC_MIS_SUM_A_THD_APP = C_FAC_MIS_SUM_A_THD_APP
Else(1)
LV_MIS_A_DIAG_REQ_APP = 0
FAC_MIS_A_THD_IND_APP = 1
FAC_MIS_SUM_A_THD_APP = 1
EndIf(1)

58.13.1 Recurrence Manager
58.13.2 Formula Section
58.13.2.1 Combination of different diagnosis reliability levels (mis?re detection, ignition, injec-
tion)
Due to their physical principle, the individual diagnostic functions have a different diagnostic relevance de-
pending on the operating point.
To achieve the best possible detection of mis?res, the individual diagnostic methods are combined. Here
with an assumed mis?re of a part function, an operating point dependent weighting factor, which re?ects the
reliability of this part function in the current operating point, is taken from a map. If the sum of these three
values now exceeds a threshold for one combustion, then mis?re is detected.
The value which is not debounced is used as input value of the IV and IGCFB diagnoses. The injection for
a cylinder is cut off exclusively by the CARB error mechanism and not by the IV and IGCFB diagnostic func-
tions.

58.13.2.1.2 Formula Section
The output from the mis?re detection, injection and ignition diagnosis functions is in?uenced by weighting
interpolated table, giving the reliability of the individual functions.
- A weighting value of 0 means that detection is not possible for this engine operating point.
- A value equal to or greater than 1 indicates reliable detection.
- The values in between represent the corresponding levels of reliability.

58.13.2.1.2.1 Ignition diagnosis weighting (IGC_DIAG_MIS)
IGC_DIAG_MIS is the not debounced carrier from Ignition diagnosis, which has to be delayed due to mis?re
detection (according segment reference SEG_NR_ER-1, cylinder x compression phase). If mis?ring is suspected
by the ignition diagnosis function, a weighting factor for the corresponding engine operating point is applied.
This factor is derived from IP_FAC_IGC_DIAG_MIS table.
For the time the number of cylinders shut off due to mis?re detection limp home reaches or exceeds the
applicable number of C_MIS_NR_OFF_IV_IGCFB, FAC_IGC_DIAG factor is forced to 1 (test based on INH_IV_MIS
carrier).

operating point is applied. This factor is derived from tables according combustion mode and determine in
application incidence. The corresponding result is in FAC_ER_DIAG_MIS data.

58.13.2.2 Mis?re detection counters (ISO 15031 Data)
These counters are incremented at each mis?re detection based on mis?re index evaluation (after crossed
diagnosis with IGC & IV OBDI diags evaluation). Thus, it s possible to determine the total number of mis?re
detected during engine lifetime and during current driving cycle.

detection.

other (if multiple exhaust cylinder bank design).

NR_ER. It already includes the delay introduced by the mis?re index chosen.

� General Information
58.14.1 Speci?c cylinder mis?re errors
� General Information
If Mis?re criterion is detected on one cylinder with at least one of the CARB_A, CARB_B1 or CARB4 default
criterions, the corresponding cylinder error is set. Each cylinder supply at least one P-code (error is set directly
without debounce). The symptom is always corresponding to the last error occurence, and the error is reseted
only when all mis?re criterions on this cylinder have disappeared.
� Application Conditions

MISF, Mis?re diagnosis by cylinders
58.14.5 Determine a defective injector or a not working ignition path in case of mis?re
� General Information
In an engine with only one injector and one ignition coil, it is not possible to determine the root cause for a
non-burning combustion. If two separate injectors per cylinder are available, a low pressure MPI and a high
pressure DI, it is possible to observe whether changing the injection mode will lead to a change in the mis?re
behaviour.
The function can be activated by a calibration switch and contains two main function parts:
1. Part A
In case of CARB A mis?re, the combustion mode will be changed and the reactivation inhibition of the
cylinder will be removed, in order to observe the mis?re fault cause. If mis?re events are still present,
an Ignition fault is set - otherwise Injector fault. If an Ignition fault is detected - both Injectors remain
shut off for the actual driving cycle. In case of Injector fault, the system changes to the second
working Injector bank in order to allow a mis?re free condition.
The combustion mode change will be active after a minimum number of CARB A windows - in order
to protect the catalyst - and a calibrated minimum PUC phase to ensure a torque-neutral reactivation
of injection. One of the injection modes will be locked for the remaining DC in case of a con?rmed
injection fault.
2. Part B
In case of CARB B mis?re, the combustion mode will be changed in order to observe the mis?re
fault cause. If mis?re events are still present, an Ignition fault is set - otherwise Injector fault.
The faulty Injection bank can be locked by calibration for the remaining DC in order to avoid emission
increase due to mis?re. The CMB mode change is performed after a calibrated min PUC phase.
Observed Mis?re fault cause: MPI/DI Injection and IGN path.
The decision for evaluation for probability of MPI injector or DI injector or Ignition fault is based on weighting
factors evaluated from number of mis?re events and number of combustion events.
The detection of mis?re due to speci?c combustion mode is done by evaluating a weighted factor for MPI and
DI mode using combustion events and mis?re events. The weighted factor is the product of mis?re events
and combustion events in speci?c mode.
A normalised factor is evaluated based on weighted factor to check the in?uence of MPI/DI on mis?re detec-
tion.

These normalized factors are used for mis?re con?rmation under speci?c combustion mode. There are two
steps to con?rm the mode leading to mis?re.
Step 1. If the normalized factor is above / below a threshold (generally 0.75/ 0.25), the con?rmation is based on
mis?re events. The mode with higher mis?re events is con?rmed as the mis?ring combustion mode.
Step 2: If the mis?ring mode is not con?rmed in above step (normalized factor inside threshold window or
equal number of mis?re events in step 1), then the decision is based on a ratio.
Ratio MPI = Mis?re event MPI / Combustion event in MPI
Ratio DI = Mis?re event DI / Combustion event in DI
If ( Ratio MPI >Ratio Di)
Then the mis?re mode is con?rmed for MPI mode of combustion
Else the mis?re mode is con?rmed for DI mode of combustion.
If each mode is having same mis?re/combustion events, then con?rmation of DI mode is set because of higher
priority is given to DI mode.

There are 3 steps of evaluation:
Step 1: Detecting probability of injector or ignition failure
Step 2: Con?rming injector or ignition failure
Step 3: Reactivation on combustion mode if a new failure is detected in MPI / DI mode after con?rmation of
injector fault in DI/ MPI mode.

MISF, Mis?re tuning functions
mis?re function, it is required to arti?cially create a mis?re scenario either by cutting of injection / inhibiting
ignition cylinder individually.
The function Mis?re Generator help the tester to create a mis?re event of pattern as mandated by the OBD
requirement. This function can be activated only for validation/calibration purposes using con?guration switch
during SW generation. It is strongly recommended to remove this functionally on serial product software:
integration choice via NLC_USE_MIS_GEN compilation switch.
The mis?re generator should be enabled during testing by a calibrateable switch LC_REQ_MIS_GEN (=1). The
mis?re generator is composed of strategies to enable 4 types of mis?re patterns.
1. No mis?re (type 0)
2. Regular Mis?re (type 1)
3. Regular loop Mis?re (type 2)
4. Dual loop (type 3)
5. Double loop (type 4)
6. Cylinder balancing mis?re (type 5)
Individual mis?re pattern is described below under relevant sections. Any pattern can be enabled individually
or it can be combined with other patterns. The pattern de?nition is done using a calibration table ID_MOD_MIS_
GEN[10][6]. This table speci?es pattern of mis?re requested, the sequence of patterns for continuous mis?re
generation, and the details of each pattern.
The table has 10 rows; each row is used to de?ne a mis?re pattern. Each column in the table speci?es details
of the chosen mis?re pattern. If no value is speci?ed in the mis?re pattern column of the table, then the mis?re
generation is stopped.
ID_MOD_MIS_GEN De?nition :
Figure 58.15.1:
The mis?re generator reads through each row of the above table and executes the requested mis?re pattern.
The label ?index_table? identi?es the row that is currently active for mis?re generation. Each mode (column 0
in above table) is identi?ed by label ?TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL?.
The column 1 (NbTdc) de?nes the window in terms of TDCs during which mis?re generator will be active.
The column 2 (Rate 1) de?nes the rate (in terms of TDCs) of mis?re event for the identi?ed cylinder.
At the end of each mode, no mis?re is allowed for C_NR_TDC_NO_MIS_GEN Tdc?s.
At the beginning of each mode ( no mis?re included ), a ?ag LV_ST_MOD_MIS_GEN is set for one TDC.
To begin with the function, row 0 (index_table = 0) is started with for the mis?re generation.

MISF, Mis?re tuning functions
58.15.1 Synchronize ignition and injection mis?re events
The mis?re generated by ignition cutoff will be active immediately in the same engine cycle, whereas the
mis?re due to injection cutoff will be active in follower engine cycle. In case of both ignition and injection
cutoff, two mis?re events will be generated; one in current engine cycle and the other in follower engine cycle.
This is not desirable to tune the mis?re function.
To synchronize the delay between ignition and injection mis?re events, the request for ignition mis?re event
should be delayed by 1 segment. This is achieved by updating the inhibition request via feedback.
If(11) CTR_NR_TDC_INH_MIS_GEN = 0
Then(11)
// delay misfire creation by calibrated number of TDCs
INH_IV_MIS_GEN = INH_IV_MIS_GEN_16
INH_IGC_MIS_GEN = INH_IGC_MIS_GEN_16
CTR_NR_TDC_INH_MIS_GEN = C_NR_TDC_INH_MIS_GEN
Else(11)
Decrement CTR_NR_TDC_INH_MIS_GEN
Endif(11)
58.15.2 Start of new mis?re pattern generation
If(1) index_table != index_table_OLD
Then(1)
CTR_NR_TDC_NO_MIS_GEN = 0 // initialize misfire delay counter
Endif(1)
index_table_old = index_table
If(2) CTR_NR_TDC_NO_MIS_GEN < C_NR_TDC_NO_MIS_GEN
Then(2)
Increment CTR_NR_TDC_NO_MIS_GEN
TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = 0
// check delay before start of new misfire pattern generation
Else(2)
// delay time is elapsed for start of new misfire pattern
// read the mode of misfire pattern that is requested
TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = ID_MOD_MIS_GEN(0,index_table)
If(3) TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL <> 0
And TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL <> TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL_old
Then(3)
// set only for the first TDC of the new mode
LV_ST_MOD_MIS_GEN = 1
Else(3)
// reset for all other TDC?s in the same mode
LV_ST_MOD_MIS_GEN = 0
Endif(3)
Endif(2)

58.15.3 Mis?re generator of speci?c pattern
There are 5 patterns of misfire that can be generated
Case 0: No misfire
Case 1: Regular misfire (only one misfire generator window)
Case 2: Regular loop misfire (NC_CYL_NR misfire generator windows)
Case 3: Dual loop misfire (NC_CYL_NR misfire generator windows)
Case 4: Double misfire (only one misfire generator window)
Case 5: CYBL triggered misfire (cylinder balancing lean-shifts ramps)
SWITCH (TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL)
{
// see sub-chapters 1.2.1, 1.2.2, 1.2.3, 1.2.4, 1.2.5 below
58.15.3.1 Case 0: NO MISFIRE (TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = 0)
// Misfire generator is stopped
CASE 0:
{
LV_MIS_GEN_REQ = 0
LV_MIS_GEN = 0
INH_IGC_MIS_GEN_16 = 0
INH_IV_MIS_GEN_16 = 0
INH_IGC_MIS_GEN = 0
INH_IV_MIS_GEN = 0
NR_TDC_MOD_MIS_GEN = 0
CTR_SEG_MIS_GEN = 0
CTR_SEG_MIS_GEN_2 = 0
CTR_SEG_MIS_GEN_CYL[NC_CYL_NR] = 0
BREAK
}
58.15.3.2 Case 1: REGULAR MISFIRE (TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = 1)
REGULAR MISFIRE: mis?re is created in the same cylinder cyclically
There are two parts:
1. Start of mis?re generator
2.
a) Mis?re generation at desired segment
b) No mis?re for other segments
3. End of mis?re generator
CASE 1:
{
// Misfire generator will be active until NR_TDC_MOD_MIS_GEN reaches the
threshold defined by ID_MOD_MIS_GEN table (column 2: NbTdc), or as long as LC_
MIS_GEN_INF = 1
If(1) LC_MIS_GEN_INF = 1
OR NR_TDC_MOD_MIS_GEN < ID_MOD_MIS_GEN(1,index_table)
Then(1)
// Start misfire generator from requested segment number

Or LV_ST_REG_SIMPLE_LOOP = 1
Then(2)

LV_MIS_GEN_REQ = 0
Else(3)
LV_MIS_GEN_REQ = 1

Then(4) NR_TDC_MOD_MIS_GEN = 0

// REGULAR MISFIRE pattern is finished

NR_TDC_MOD_MIS_GEN = 0
Increment index_table // prepare for next misfire pattern
LV_MIS_GEN_REQ = 0
CTR_SEG_MIS_GEN = 0
INH_IGC_MIS_GEN_16 = 0
INH_IV_MIS_GEN_16 = 0
Endif(1)
BREAK
}
58.15.3.3 Case 2: REGULAR LOOP MISFIRE (TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = 2) AND Case 3: DUAL
LOOP MISFIRE (TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = 3)
REGULAR LOOP MISFIRE: mis?re is generated in all cylinders successively for one complete generation win-
dow.
Eg. In a 3 cylinder engine, mis?re generator will be active for 3 generator windows; in each window it will
create mis?re on a selected cylinder. The generator starts from cylinder 0. So sequence will be cyl 0, window
0; cyl 1, window 1; cyl 2, window 2.
DUAL LOOP MISFIRE: mis?re is generated in all cylinders successively for one complete generation window.
The difference with the ?REGULAR LOOP? is that the cylinder on the same physical segment is also triggered
with mis?re, within one engine cycle, after generating mis?re on cylinder that was requested.
Eg. In a 4 cylinder engine, mis?re generator will be active for 4 generator windows; in each window it
will create mis?re on a selected cylinder and the coupling cylinder (on same physical segment). The generator

58.15.3.4 Case 4: DOUBLE MISFIRE (TMP_C_MOD_MIS_GEN_TBL = 4)
DOUBLE MISFIRE: mis?re is generated in two cylinders cyclically within one generator window.
Eg. In a 4 cylinder engine, mis?re generator can be made active on cylinder 1 and 2 at different mis?re
rates. Cylinder 1 mis?re rate can be calibrated in ID_MOD_MIS_GEN column 3 and Cylinder 2 mis?re rate can
be calibrated in ID_MOD_MIS_GEN column 5.
So, two cylinders will be mis?ring at independent rates in the same generator window.
There are two parts:
1. Start of mis?re generator
2.
a) Mis?re generation on desired cylinder
b) No mis?re for other segments
3. End of mis?re generator

58.16.1.2 B03F_01 : Mis?re detection engine parameters
� General Information
In this chapter, LOAD_MIS is de?ned as a "transparent" engine load independently of the EMS structure type
(based on MAP, MAF, TQI or else...). This variable is strictly dedicated to the mis?re monitoring process. It al-
lows commuting from one reference to another depending on different conditions (engine combustion mode,
engine states or others).
This engine load is essentially used for:
? Zero load line de?nition
? Engine load breakpoint de?nition for mis?re detection thresholds, gradient detections, catalyst destruc-
tion threshold ...
Today, engine load LOAD_MIS is de?ned as a ratio between the current system variable used for system control
(see application system de?nition) and its maximum value.
MPI in MAP structure: LOAD_MIS = MAP / C_MAP_MAX_MIS
MPI in MAF structure: LOAD_MIS = MAF / IP_MAF_MAX_MIS(N_32)
MPI in Torque structure: LOAD_MIS = TQI_AV / IP_TQI_AV_MAX_MIS(N_32)
For MAF and TQI_AV, the maximum reached values partly depend on engine speed. The normalisations
according IP_MAF_MAX_MIS & IP_TQI_AV_MAX_MIS allow reaching 100% of the engine load independently of
the engine speed.

Hint: LOAD_MIS can be based on TQI_AV (actual indicated torque value). But with torque structure, TQI_AV
quick torque requests can induce noise on detection threshold determination; so on some applications it?s
better to use MAF or MAP and multiply LOAD_MIS by ignition ef?ciency to correct torque reductions.
GDI structure: one or two engine load references can be used MAP/MAF & TQI_AV.
MAP or MAF system variables can be used for homogeneous combustion modes (AFS and AFL) and
TQI_AV or MFF for strati?ed combustion (engine torque mainly proportional to fuel mass).
TQI_AV can also be used for homogenous and strati?ed combustion modes (but take care on noise
ratio).
Remark: MAF information has a slower response regarding to MAP for dynamic behaviour of the strategy
(could depend on applications).
58.16.1.2.1 Module calibration prerequisites
Airpath calibrated
Legal target known (for zero load line de?nition)
Engine speed redline known, engine capable to reach this engine speed (for US applications)
58.16.1.2.2 Calibration Step B03F_01 - Step 1 / 1
58.16.1.2.2.1 Calibration of engine load reference LOAD_MIS
C_MAP_MAX_MIS is often set to MAP maximum value obtain on your application (LOAD_MIS = 100%),
but can be minimised next to have the best full-scale ratio for mean weather/altitude conditions ( ?1014hPa).
No correction for atmospheric pressure is included due to the large ER signal noise ratio at high engine load.
IP_MAF_MAX_MIS is often set to MAF maximum value observed on the application (see air path
calibration step and intake architecture) for each engine speed, but can also be minimised next to have the
best full scale ratio for mean intake conditions.
IP_TQI_AV_MAX_MIS, is an image of the maximum torque setpoint reached in the engine torque
reference map for each engine speed breakpoint.
According maximum MAF and/or TQI_AV characterization vs. engine speed that can be reached by our en-
gine, de?ne these calibrations in a way to reach LOAD_MIS = 100% for each engine speed when in wide open
throttle.
58.16.1.2.2.2 Calibration of the engine zero load line
LOAD_MIN_MIS, the engine zero load line is based on a basic shape (zero torque line plus legal inhibition
triangle de?ned according legal target), a coolant temperature correction and an atmospheric pressure cor-
rection.
58.16.1.2.2.2.1 Basic zero load line de?nition
Basic zero load line are determinated according, the transmission type (MT, AT) & the combustion mode (AFS,
AFL or S)
Conditions: hot engines, low friction, no consumers, low altitude
� Determination:
First with hot engine, drive the engine forced in desired combustion mode; with no gear engaged for manual
transmission or in neutral for automatic transmission in all speed points (idle speed, 1000 rpm to max. engine
speed for OBDII applications by step of 500 rpm) and note the load (LOAD_MIS[%], and/or MAP and TQI_AV
engine parameter).
Test has to be evaluated on several engines/transmissions to take in account engine/car ?uctuations.
Calibrate the values of IP_LOAD_MIN_MIS_xx_yy 5% below these values in the speed area up to 3000 rpm in a
way to be able to detect mis?re in idle speed & close to the zero load line.
This basic calibration will be ?rstly evaluated with constant TCO value, as a consequence IP_LOAD_MIN_MIS_
xx_yy will be de?ned as an unique row.

58.16.1.2.2.2.2 OBD II triangular offset
In the CARB mail-out #96-34, the disablement region from 3000 rpm to 6000 rpm is described with a line
from 3000 rpm to 6000 rpm and the load increased with 4 inch Hg at 6000 rpm (i.e. 135 hPa). In this region,
an offset has to be added. For that, a correspondence between 135 hPa offset and a LOAD_MIS offset has to
be evaluated.
This offset can be applied by the calibrations IP_LOAD_MIN_OFS_AMP_MIS_xx_yy, evaluated at sea level.
58.16.1.2.2.2.3 E-OBD triangular offset
TThe disablement region from 3000 rpm to the max. speed (i.e.: minimum between 4500 or 1000 greater the
highest speed occurring in ECE + EUDC cycle) is described with a line from 3000 rpm to the max. speed and
the load increased with 133 hPa at this maximum speed. For that, a correspondence between 135 hPa offset
and a LOAD_MIS offset has to be evaluated (if LOAD_MIS not based on MAP).

58.16.2 Tuning hints for generic fade out conditions for mis?re detection (B03F_02)
� General Information
Generic fade out ?ag (LV_REQ_APP_INH_MIS) is based on all conditions that could create unreliable conditions
for mis?re detection :
? Engine gradients (engine load, engine speed, throttle, combustion mode & ignition angle transients).
? Crankshaft jolt effects that can disturb detection process (rough road, drivetrain oscillations, and air
conditioner & accessories activation/deactivation).
? OBDI errors on one of the sensors used by the mis?re monitoring process.
All these different conditions are merge into a carrier (MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH).
58.16.2.1 Calibration advice for US applications
For OBD-II, take care that on a complete reference cycle this fade-out occurs to often, in the course of time
the CARB reduce more and more the possibilities to use fade out based on IGA, TPS, MAF transients. In any
case see with the executive of?cer the possibility to keep this functionality if you can provide an engineering
evaluation to prove that you aren?t able to detect mis?re in such case in reliable conditions.
58.16.2.2 Module calibration prerequisites
Good vehicle driveability (at least 80% of the driveability calibration reached)
58.16.2.3 Calibration Step B03F_02 - Step 1 / 2
Module precalibration
A short way to disable all the generic fade-out described in this chapter is to set carrier masks to zero (all
fade-out disabled).
C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS = 0
C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS = 0
C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS_IS = 0
Thus MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH_NR & LV_REQ_APP_INH_MIS will be always set to 0.
58.16.2.4 Calibration Step B03F_02 - Step 2 / 2
58.16.2.4.1 Con?gurable generic fade-outs management
A maskable fade-out management has been introduced to answer to the incertitude of the ?nal 2002 CARB
mail-out contents (always a draft up to now), especially for the fade-out management during and out of the
"zero delay" phase. Moreover, as quite all fade-out must be discussed and justi?ed to the executive of?cer,
depending on results some fade-out could be cancelled in last minutes.
This maskable fade-out management can be very useful during calibration steps to remove non-tuneable
fade-outs like OBDI errors and/or external function requests.
The maskable fade-out management can totally con?gure the fade-outs required or not for the legal target
you require.
All generic fade-out conditions (LV_INH_xxx ?ags) are merged within a carrier structure MIS_DET_CDN_APP_INH
(see de?nition below).
Three different mask calibrations (C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS during & C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS / C_
MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS_IS out of ZDLY period) are applied on this carrier to evaluate the number of fade-out
?ags set to 1 and validated by the masking.
Example: C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS = 0x00 will disable all generic fade-outs during the ZDLY & C_
MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS = 0x7FF will enable all generic fade-outs out of the ZDLY period in part load & C_
MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS_IS = 0x7FF will enable all generic fade-outs out of the ZDLY period in idle speed.

Example: C_MASK_APP_INH_DET_ZDLY_MIS = 0x00 will disable all generic fade-outs during the ZDLY & C_
MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS = 0x7FF will enable all generic fade-outs out of the ZDLY period in part load & C_
MASK_APP_INH_DET_MIS_IS = 0x7FF will enable all generic fade-outs out of the ZDLY period in idle speed.

58.16.2.4.2 Maximum manifold air-pressure gradient
Due to trailing throttle / acceleration transition problems (especially for engines with dual mass ?ywheels), it
could be necessary to disable mis?re detection for a short period when the manifold air-pressure gradient
exceeds an applicable value.
To evaluate the fade-out necessary in such conditions, please check at the transitions from fuel cut off to part
load and vice versa as well as all transitions from low load to high load, if some speed ?uctuations are critical
for misdetection of mis?re.
Measure in parallel the different engine load like informations available (TPS, MAP, MAF, TQI_AV & LOAD_MIS)
who will be necessary for others fade-out calibrations (L V_INH_LOAD_GRD_DET_MIS, L V_INH_TPS_GRD_DET_
MIS).
For LV_INH_MAP_DIF_DET_MIS determination, look at which load difference the engine speed ?uctuation is
suf?ciently forced to increase the risk of wrong mis?re detection (to be evaluated regarding ER, THD_ER &
N_GRD values, use of ER_THD_RATIO would be appreciated if integrated, see mis?re detection App. Inc. ?le).

Not necessary and/or unjusti?ed fade out at normal load conditions should be avoided according CARB re-
quirements for US applications (no fade-out based on TPS, Loads, MAP gradients should occur on FTP cy-

Fade out allowed for US:" ... engine speed, load, or torque transients due to throttle movements more rapid than

Note for strati?ed combustion: as in strati?ed combustion, the MAP information isn?t relative to the engine

58.16.2.5 Maximum throttle gradient
Due to trailing throttle / acceleration transient problems at low load, it is necessary to disable mis?re detection
for a short period when the throttle gradient exceeds an applicable value
Re-use the ?les obtained for LV_INH_MAP_DIF_DET_MIS calibration and look at which throttle gradient the
engine speed ?uctuation is suf?ciently forced to increase the risk of wrong mis?re detection (to be evaluated
regarding ER, THD_ER & N_GRD values).
The fade out through throttle gradient normally works at the transition from part load to fuel-cut-off. The air
mass gradient is in this case too slow (LOAD_MIS based on MAF) and TPS_GRD is more accurate than MAP in
such conditions.
Remark: The most critical point is a short time before undershoot the zero load line.
Evaluate in such conditions TPS_GRD versus TPS_AV to calibrate the IP_TPS_GRD_MAX_MIS calibration map.
C_T_TPS_GRD_DLY_MIS must be set from 1.5 to 2 times the longest disturbance on ER index due to TPS_GRD
you?ve observed during these same tests.
Note for US: after discussion with our internal OBD Program Coordinator, it has been decided to introduce
a speci?c TPS_GRD based fade-out during Zero Delay phase. This fade-out is dedicated to engine cranking
mis?re monitoring. IP_TPS_GRD_ZDLY_MIS must be greater than IP_TPS_GRD_MAX_MIS in a way to not trigger
fade-out during nominal engine cranking, except when TPS is highly driver induced.
C_T_TPS_GRD_DLY_ZDLY_MIS must be set from 1.5 to 2 times the longest disturbance on ER index due to
TPS_GRD you?ve observed during the ?Zero Delay Period?(5s after engine start).

Mis?re detection can be disabled when the amount of engine load gradient exceeds a calibration value, this

Re-use the former ?les obtained for LV_INH_MAP_DIF_DET_MIS calibration and look at which LOAD_GRD_MIS
the engine speed ?uctuation is suf?ciently forced to increase the risk of wrong mis?re detection (to be evalu-

Note for GDI Applications:
In strati?ed combustion mode, LV_INH_LOAD_GRD_DET_MIS is the main engine load gradient fade-out. An
accurate calibration is required in such mode especially in idle speed and at low engine load (close to strati?ed
LOAD_MIN_MIS values).
Test pro?les required for calibration in strati?ed are mainly low engine and part-load up to the highest engine
speed where strati?ed combustion is active.
In the same way C_T_LOAD_GRD_S_DLY_MIS must be set from 1.5 to 2 times the longest disturbance on ER
index due to LOAD_GRD_MIS you?ve observed during strati?ed combustion tests.
58.16.2.7 Ignition retardation without change limitation
Various functions and/or CAN requests (e.g.. gearshift signal, traction control, torque structure reduction. etc...)
could cause an ignition angle retardation.
Mis?re detection can be disabled when the amount of the ignition timing retardation changes is too important
OR/AND when the global ignition timing retardation is too important.
The fade-out conditions are split in 2 modes:
? 2 calibrations maps focus on the IGA transients (cylinder to cylinder)
IP_DEL TA_IGA_IS_MIS is used to detect unreliable conditions for detection according a certain amount of igni-
tion angle transients. only used in idle speed.
IP_DEL TA_IGA_MIS is used to detect unreliable conditions for detection according a certain amount of
ignition angle transients. only used in part load.
? 1 calibration map focus on the difference between the basic ignition angle and the current one.
IP_DEL TA_IGA_BAS_MIS is used to detect unreliable conditions for detection due to an important ignition angle
retardation (rough combustions).
The experience has often shown that an advance reduction of 10�Crk could cause a torque ?uctuation that can
be critical for the mis?re detection in lowest engine load conditions (lowest signal noise ratio on ER index).
Critical points : focus on low engine load with strong IGA corrections, idle speed & any torque reduction request
case
Therefore, check at low and medium load and speed conditions at such advance (torque) reductions, if any
problem occurs with mis?re detection (ER decreases) and how long the disturbance last.
If there is any problem, calibrate the table to fade out for the duration of the disturbance; otherwise calibrate
20�Crk and a minimum duration of 10 tdc?s.
Note for strati?ed combustion: as in strati?ed combustion, IGA corrections (if they exist) have minimum in-
?uence on engine load, LV_INH_IGA_DIF_DET_MIS is always set to 0 in such mode. The torque reduction in
strati?ed is managed by LOAD_MIS gradient that is directly relative to torque information is such case.
58.16.2.8 Combustion mode transients
While the combustion manager is in transient state (change from a torque reference to another), the mis?re
detection must be disabled to have a proper base for the evaluation of the ER-mis?re detection thresholds,
which are de?ned for the stationary modes (AFS, AFL & S).
When combustion mode transients occur, during a certain number of Tdc?s due to ER delay, LOAD_MIS and
threshold maps switch, the mis?re detection could be disturbed.
The experience has shown that a fade out of 8 tdc?s for C_NR_TDC_CMB_TRA_S_MIS and C_NR_TDC_CMB_TRA_
AFL_MIS is a minimum number. To be evaluated on each application according the driveability calibration
target applied for the whole combustion structure.
58.16.2.9 Air - conditioning compressor activation
When the air - conditioning compressor is switched on, an additional load is brie?y applied to the engine. This
load jump can cause a segment period jump and crankshaft vibration, depending on the engine operating
state and load request.

To be evaluated on each application according the driveability calibration
target applied for the whole combustion structure.
58.16.2.9 Air - conditioning compressor activation
When the air - conditioning compressor is switched on, an additional load is brie?y applied to the engine. This
load jump can cause a segment period jump and crankshaft vibration, depending on the engine operating
state and load request.
For C_T_ACCOUT_DLY_MIS calibration, check at different engine speed and load points, if the engine roughness
ER could produce wrong mis?re detection at the turn-on and off of the air conditioning compressor and the
duration of the disturbance that could occur.
Calibrate this delay 2 times the longest disturbance you?ve observed.
